title: Question 26

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She feels well, has no medical problems, and takes no medications. Medical history is remarkable only for an episode of pyelonephritis treated with a 3-day hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics after the birth of her last child at age 42 years.
Physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows trace leukocyte esterase, and two subsequent urine cultures reveal more than 10
cfu/mL of
Escherichia coli
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Asymptomatic bacteriuria does not require treatment.
Screening for and treating asymptomatic bacteriuria are indicated only in pregnancy and before invasive urologic procedures.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) does not require treatment (
Option D
). ASB is defined as the presence of at least 10

cfu/mL of a uropathogen from two consecutive voided urine specimens in women or one specimen in men. In all cases, local or systemic signs or symptoms of infection are absent. The prevalence of ASB ranges from 1% to 5% in healthy premenopausal women (2%-10% in pregnant women) to nearly 100% in patients with long-term indwelling urinary catheters. The bacteria responsible for ASB are the same as those associated with symptomatic infections of the urinary tract.
Escherichia coli

is the organism isolated most often. Evidence shows that treating ASB has no effect on the incidence of symptomatic urinary tract infections (UTIs), prevalence of bacteriuria, or survival. Screening for or treating ASB is not indicated in nonpregnant women or patients with diabetes mellitus, spinal cord injuries, or chronic indwelling urinary catheters. Treatment of these populations puts the patients at risk for drug adverse effects and increases the probability of antibiotic resistance. Screening for and treating ASB is indicated only in pregnancy and before invasive urologic procedures. Untreated ASB in pregnant women may be complicated by premature delivery, a low–birth-weight infant, or pyelonephritis. Untreated ASB in patients undergoing urologic procedures associated with mucosal trauma can increase the risk for postoperative UTIs and sepsis.

Antibiotic treatment is not required for this patient with ASB. Preferred agents for the treatment of cystitis include nitrofurantoin (5 days), trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMS) (3 days), and fosfomycin (1 dose). In geographic areas where TMS resistance exceeds 20%, an alternative agent should be selected. β-Lactam agents (including amoxicillin-clavulanate [
Option A

], cefdinir, cefaclor, and cefpodoxime proxetil, each 3-7 days) are considered acceptable alternative second-line therapies. β-Lactams, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, are not preferred for cystitis if other recommended agents are available, because they are less effective in eradicating infection.
Nitrofurantoin (
Option B
) is an excellent choice for cystitis but is not required in this patient with ASB.
Repeat urinalysis and urine culture (
Option C
) will likely provide similar results and may document the presence of ASB but will not help in managing this patient.

objective.__html: Manage a patient with asymptomatic bacteriuria.

references: Nicolle LE, Gupta K, Bradley SF, et al. Clinical practice guideline for the management of asymptomatic bacteriuria: 2019 update by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clin Infect Dis. 2019;68:e83-e110.
